name: UV / Haze
about: Standard protective glass. No measurable light reduction. Primarily used to cut atmospheric haze and protect the front element.

name: K2 Yellow (No. 8)
about: Standard contrast filter for B&W. Darkens blue skies to increase cloud definition. Corrects tonal range for traditional emulsions.

name: O2 Orange (No. 21)
about: Strong contrast for B&W. Significant darkening of blue/green spectrums. Increases haze penetration in landscape photography.

name: R2 Red (No. 25)
about: Dramatic contrast for B&W. Turns blue skies near-black. Note: Check film red-sensitivity; some stocks (e.g. Fomapan) may require an extra 0.5 stop.

name: CPL Polarizer
about: Used to cut reflections and deepen sky saturation. Light reduction varies by rotation (average 1.5 stops).

name: ND4 (2-Stop)
about: Neutral Density. Uniformly reduces light across the spectrum by 2 stops without altering color balance.

name: ND8 (3-Stop)
about: Neutral Density. Uniformly reduces light by 3 stops. Ideal for extending shutter speeds in bright daylight.

name: ND1000 (10-Stop)
about: Extreme Neutral Density. Used for long-exposure effects like smoothing water. May introduce minor IR color casts on certain film stocks.
